artworkData.intro: Watteau’s Pleasures of the Ball depicts a group of elegantly dressed French elites dancing, making music, and enjoying each other’s company on an outdoor terrace. But the inclusion of two apparently enslaved Black figures in the picture raises the question of whose pleasure we are seeing, and at what cost.

provenanceEvents.title: 1. Watteau’s fêtes galantes and Black subjects
provenanceEvents.text:
Watteau painted the Pleasures of the Ball around 1715-17. He is best known for inventing the fête galante, a genre representing elegant elites entertaining each other in an idyllic outdoor setting. This same period coincided with the inclusion of Black figures in Watteau’s paintings and drawings, some of whom appear to have been modeled from life.

Watteau’s Pleasures is one of several fêtes galantes that includes Black figures: a young boy in the crowd and another who stands on a balcony at the far right and looks down at the dancers. He wears a turban and possibly (though it is less clear) a metal collar, which would denote his enslavement. The presence of enslaved African and Afro-descended individuals—most of whom were trafficked from France’s Caribbean colonies to serve as domestic laborers in the metropole—was increasing in Paris at this moment, and the inclusion of these Black figures makes us wonder: What was the artist’s own opinion about this practice? What does it mean that he seems to have made the boy on the balcony a surrogate spectator? How does this change our understanding of the painting and the fête galante genre as being preoccupied with pleasure? “Pleasure” at whose cost?
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Antoine Watteau, Three Studies of a Young Man, c. 1715-16. Gray wash with red and black chalk on paper, 24.3 x 27 cm. Musée du Louvre. © GrandPalaisRmn (musée du Louvre) / Michel Urtado.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Antoine Watteau, Three Studies of a Young Man, c. 1715-16. Musée du Louvre.

provenanceEvents.title: 2. Watteau and his colonial patrons at the Hôtel Crozat
provenanceEvents.text:
Watteau painted the Pleasures of the Ball around the same time he was living in the Parisian hôtel of his principal patron, Pierre Crozat (1665-70). (This same hôtel on the rue Richelieu would later be the residence of the duc de Choiseul.)  

While the Black figure in Pleasures is inspired by works by Veronese and other artists Crozat collected, his presence raises the question of whether Watteau could have based the figure on a real-life enslaved model in Paris.

Pierre Crozat and his brother Antoine made their fortunes in maritime speculation, and from 1712-17 Antoine had a commercial monopoly on French Louisiana and controlled part of France’s slave trade. Despite royal restrictions, it would have been easy for the Crozats and their friends to traffic enslaved individuals into Paris, and indeed in 1716 the Crown relaxed such restrictions, acknowledging the desire among metropolitan elites for enslaved domestic servants.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Nicolas Lancret, Concert in the Oval Salon of Pierre Crozat’s Château at Montmorency, c. 1719-20. Oil on canvas, 35.56 x 44.45 cm. Dallas Art Museum, Lent by the Michael L. Rosenberg Foundation.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: Nicolas Lancret, Concert in the Oval Salon of Pierre Crozat’s Château at Montmorency, c. 1719-20. Dallas Art Museum.

provenanceEvents.title: 3. Dyeing for Watteau: the Glucq family
provenanceEvents.text:
An early owner of Pleasures of the Ball was Claude Glucq (1676-1742), a celebrated Watteau collector who also briefly owned The Shopsign of Gersaint. Claude’s father Jean had made his fortune as a master thread dyer (he specialized in scarlet textiles made with cochineal) and was one of the largest shareholders in the Mississippi Company, which took over the monopoly on France’s North American and West Indian colonies from Antoine Crozat.

In 1715, Jean acquired a massive property along Paris’s Quai Voltaire for his family, and Claude may have displayed Pleasures there, although he himself also bought a château in Massy near Paris that he named “Virginie.” However, Claude’s own colonial speculations bankrupted him before he could embellish the property, and he ended up having to sell most of his art collection.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: Photograph of the Quai Voltaire, Paris with the Glucq family hôtel at the far right. Image source: Wikimedia.

provenanceEvents.title: 4. The Afterlife of Pleasures: Julienne, Vaudreuil, and Le Brun
provenanceEvents.text:
Pleasures of the Ball was later owned by Glucq’s cousin Jean de Jullienne (1686-1766), another fervent Watteau patron. His uncle had partnered with Glucq’s father to establish a business that later became the Gobelins textile manufactory. Jullienne, who followed his family’s tradition in investing in colonial trade (specifically, as Charlotte Guichard points out, in indigo to dye textiles), took over managing the Gobelins in 1729, and he built a residence onsite that housed his extensive art collection. Another cousin named Montullé to whom Julienne bequeathed the collection oversaw the creation of a beautiful album depicting rooms in which these artwokrs were displayed, although it doesn’t specify where Pleasures was hung.

In 1783, the comte de Vaudreuil bought Watteau’s painting at Montullé’s posthumous sale, but he flipped it a few years later. Soon after it passed through the hands of the dealer Jean-Baptiste-Pierre Le Brun, who bought and sold scores of artworks for colonial clients, many of whom were portrayed by his wife Elisabeth Vigée Le Brun.
provenanceEvents.imageSource: French School, Catalogue des tableaux de Mr. de Julienne (compiled by Montullé), 18th Century, detail of p. 50. Pen and black ink, gray wash, and watercolor on paper, 19.6 x 26 cm. The Morgan Library and Museum, New York City.
provenanceEvents.imageAlt: French School, Catalogue des tableaux de Mr. de Julienne, 18th Century. The Morgan Library and Museum, New York City.

nodes.bio: A French painter whose elegant fête galantes and theatrical scenes won him the patronage and high esteem of Parisian collectors, nobles, and amateurs, including the wealthy financier Pierre Crozat. Many of his paintings feature Black, probably enslaved, attendants, suggesting his awareness of their growing presence in the French capital alongside the expansion of colonial commerce.

A wealthy French banker and preeminent art collector whose extensive patronage supported leading artists of his time, including Watteau (who lived at one point in his Parisian mansion) and Charles de La Fosse. His brother and business partner, Antoine Crozat (c. 1655-1783), built an immense fortune from colonial investments, including slave trading, and was the first proprietary owner of French Louisiana (from 1712-1717).

Glucq’s father, Jean, was a master dyer whose factory supplied brilliant colors (made with colonial materials like cochineal) to the Gobelins royal tapestry manufactory. He passed that business along with his fortune gained through colonial commerce and slave trading to his son Claude, who became a major art collector known for his patronage of Watteau. At one point Claude owned Watteau’s Shopsign of Gersaint and many other works by modern French artists.

A cousin of Claude Glucq, Jean de Jullienne was an esteemed art collector, amateur, and close friend of Watteau who led a project to reproduce the artist’s work (the Receuil Julienne). He followed his family in colonial investments, specifically trading in indigo produced with enslaved labor, and he eventually took over managing the Gobelins manufactory, where he built a house to display his extensive art collection.

Born in Saint-Domingue, where his father served as colonial governor, Vaudreuil moved to Paris and later became one of the capital’s most voracious art collectors. His family owned several sugar plantations worked by enslaved laborers in Saint-Domingue, and he used the profits from these plantations to buy art and to commission new works by celebrated painters like Elisabeth Vigée Le Brun, who may have been his lover.

A painter, engraver, and collector of art, Le Brun is best known for his activities as an art dealer and for his marriage to the celebrated painter Élisabeth Vigée-Le Brun (1755-1842). He bought art and organized sales for most of the planter collectors in this colonial network, and during the French Revolution he helped the new government seize these same artworks from the collectors’ homes and bring them to the Louvre.
